div1.p: Reed must postpone his visit to see her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, January 24, 1876
div1.p:
Your former
very much abbreviated epistle
recalled vividly to mind a
certain remark, said to have
emanated from one W. Shakes-
peare, but which I doubt
whether I can quote correct-
ly. 'Twas somewhat after
this fashion: “if 'twere done, when
'twere done, 'twere well it were done quickly.” I am not
quite satisfied whether
'twere well to use 3 or 4
“'tweres”, Yet I am inclined to
think that 3 will answer.
It may be that the reception
of my last letter brought to
your memory the identi-
cal sentence- If so, by all
means tell me, since it
would be proof irresistible
that our minds, or what is
the same thing, “great minds
run in the same channel”-
What thought you of that
letter? As for myself, I con-
sidered yours as being
simply charming- Short
but so expressive- Containing
in a “nut-shell” all that I
like most to hear- “You (mean-
ing me of course- Happy mor-
tal that I am to be singled
out, among the millions that
tread this earth- not “that one”,
or “the other one,” but “You”.)
“are not forgotten”- Ah!
I never knew what a wonder-
ful word that one little word
“not” is. I had always thought
that “nots” were rather tough
customers to encounter, and
that their negative qualities
never did any body good- But
I find that I am mistaken,
and for all the unkind words
that I have uttered against
them I herewith abjectly
apologize. “You are not for-
gotten”- No! thank Heaven, though
absent, yet am I still remem-
bered, and that, too, by a darling
angel- “Forgotten”! may this never
be my lot! Be it spring or
winter, do not forget me, my
own darling, but think of
your poor little boy; now and
always! “You are not forgotten,
my dear friend”- Those three words
are a fortune in themselves-
“My”- Am I then yours? I ask no more! and “dear” to you?
Be still my heart, lest thou
break with joy! “Friend”- Yes.
Now a “friend”, but hopes to be
more than “friend”- “By your own
Emilie.” Not only am I yours, but
you are mine- “Your own Emilie”-
Yes, and ever will be! And now
to reproduce the whole letter-
“You are not forgotten, my dear
friend, by your own Emilie”-
I calmly defy the whole world
to reproduce, a more expressive
and affectionate letter! You
may consider it a “feeble ef-
fort;” but I do not, my darling.
Not only do I kiss the very page
upon which it is written, but
I will keep it constantly, always
in my mind.
I am glad to see, my darling,
that you look upon the dis-
appointments of this life
so calmly- Yet I am sorry
that I must needs be the
cause for the exercise of this
virtue- To explain at once,
I find that I must postpone
my visit till a later day than
February- This Is much regret,
but circumstances, which I
need not relate, compel me
to do so. I am the more dis-
appointed inasmuch as I
shall miss the musical en-
tertainments- I trust, however,
that my absence will not
lessen your enjoyment, and
after you have enjoyed them,
don't forget to write me a full
account of them. I will not
fix a time for my visit, as
I might possibly be again dis-
appointed- I intend to write
to Ma & see whether I can
time my visit so as to meet
her in Murfreesboro- If I
should succeed, be pre-
pared for “rumors”-
div1.closer:
Adieu, my darling,-
Believe me, as ever,
your fond & devoted Walter.
P.S.
Excuse penmanship, as the ink
is of the very meanest sort
W.
